Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2012 01:14PM topless wrote: Cool breeze, you didn't offend this nurse, but just as info, most RN'S have 4 years of college. That said, yes, Tillycat, you should speak to her supervisor and let it be known that you were uncomfortable with this nurse's conversation and would rather not have her assigned to you again. The nurse needs to know that this was out of line and not her place to explore. She needs to ponder what she said and why she said it with the supervisor. The supervisor needs to know that this nurse may not be a good fit for this area of patient care and at the very least needs to be watched more carefully. After almost 30 yrs of nursing I have been in the same situation as the floor nurse and as a supervisor. Hopefully this incident will become a positive factor in this nurse's growth in her profession. Teaching goes both ways; nurses teach patients and patients teach nurses. You can be part of her education.
Posts.Title: Is this nurse slightly crazy? Tillycat K-Lo

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2011 10:47AM topless wrote: Ever since Kate Middelton's dress there has been a big uptic in brides asking for that look.  Maybe sleeves are making a comeback and you could be a trendsetter.  I bet if you just start  looking around you will see more dresses like that.  Good luck and best wishes for your new life!

Posts.Title: Please post your favorite or an inspiring quote BarbRocks marymoir

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2012 02:36PM topless wrote: I had a bilateral mastectomy and 10 days later I was in the hospital for a small bowel blockage.  My veins are not so good after 5 years of monthly infusions of my med for multiple sclerosis and it was a protracted and painful process to find a vein in ER.  That vein didn't hold up very long after pushing a lot of fluids and meds.  A nurse practitioner came to my room and put a PICC line in and it was like night and day.  The procedure didn't hurt (other than the little poke for lidocaine) and I had freedom to move around more and meds didn't hurt anymore.  I went home with the PICC in for a week and had no problem with it.  I haven't restarted my MS med yet, but when I do I won't hesitate to have a PICC line put in if my veins are still poor.  I may eventually have to have a port put in.  Don't worry about a PICC, it's easy and way better than having them hunt around around for a vein for chemo every month.
Posts.Title: PICC lines ridergirl virginiab

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2012 09:52PM topless wrote: Even before my BMX I was hooked on a double body pillow.  It's shaped like a huge horse shoe so which ever side I sleep on I am automatically on a body pillow.  I have multiple sclerosis and was advised to try this type of body support to help ease spacisity at night.  I love, love, love my pillow!  I haven't had the problem you mentioned but you might find that this type of body pillow might work better.

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2011 02:04PM topless wrote: Thanks all for the support.  Just hearing that others struggle with this helps.  I certainly will continue to "fake it until you make it" .
Posts.Title: I miss my breasts! topless karen1956

Posts.Content: topless wrote: I had a 1.5 slow growing infitrating tumor in my left breast.  I also have multiple sclerosis and interstitial cystitis.  30+ yrs ago I had sudden onset ulcerating colitis with toxic megacolon.  All of my large colon, anus and rectum were removed in emergency surgery at Mayo's.  I have lived with an ileostomy ever since.  Because I'm run down from a year of progressing MS and the fact that the tumor (pure mucinous type) couldn't be seen with even a magnifying mammo and I have (had) lumpy breasts I decided to have bilateral mastectomies done.  The sentinal node biopsy came back negative, the tumor margins were clear to 1 inch and no atypical tissue was seen in the right breast.  I look down at my flat chest covered in steri strips with drains dangling and wonder if I was too radical I my decsion?   I will have to live with this forever.  Now I am a 60 yr old woman with no breasts, an ileostomy, and mulstiple sclerosis.  It was bad before but now it's even worse.  Will I feel better about it after the pain and drains are gone?   I guess I beat cancer but at what price? Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Did I do the right thing? topless lwarstler

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2011 05:24PM topless wrote: Thanks for the kind thoughts and good wishes.  I am not a candidate for reconstruction because of the immune system diseases.  I know that I did the right thing.
Posts.Title: Did I do the right thing? topless lwarstler

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2011 06:00PM topless wrote: OK, I changed my name to topless but I still feel beat up.  Also piled-on, "plaything of the gods" and having no luck but bad luck in the health department.  But I will start walking (more like controlled stumbling) as soon as I'm stronger and will get back to pilates and indoor rowing as it gets colder.  But having MS is a facing a lifetime of small losses and constant greiving for what you've lost and can no longer do. With my breast cancer the only thing I can no longer do is go topless in public, according to another topic on this board. (At 60 yrs of age and short hair, would anyone really notice?)  So in a way I'm lucky that I don't have to face radiation and chemo like many of you ladies do.  Too me you are the true Cancer Survivors, I'm just a former cancer patient and that part is all over for me.  Until I look down my shirt.
Posts.Title: Did I do the right thing? topless lwarstler

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2011 08:20AM topless wrote: I am not in need, but I don't know what micro bead breast forms are.  Can you give me a little inservice?
Posts.Title: Free pair Microbead breast forms goldiebelle Sonata

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2011 07:26PM topless wrote: How about men?  They are flat chested.  Are they prone to posture problems too?  Funny I never heard about that in my 28 yrs of nursing.  That's such an idiotic line.  I never did go to any fitters even though my doc gave me a prescription that I didn't ask for and had no intention using.  I go flat chested or stick little Target "cutlets" in my old bras if I want to fit into something special.  I giggled when someone mentioned how the fitter couldn't imagine her husband not wanting her to wear foobies to bed.  I would just give my husbnd the foobies to play with any time he wanted to and I would be comfortably flat in bed.
Posts.Title: Bad Experience at the fitter? crystalphm 3jaysmom

Posts.Content: topless wrote: Being intimate with my husband is so hard now.  I just feel like I'm going through the motions as an androgynous nobody.  This is the hardest part of having had mastectomies.  He says it dosen't make any difference to him but it does to me!  This is so sad for me.  I didn't expect this at all.  I'm 60 and age has slowly taken its toll on my sexual life and now I feel like there is nothing left of the feminine side of me.  This is depressing me more than having had a permanent ileostomy since I was 24.  Somehow that didn't change my sexual identity as much as this has.  Maybe it had to do with being only 24 too - more hormones I guess.  Sigh. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: I miss my breasts! topless karen1956

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2011 04:23PM topless wrote: Oh Nowords, I wasn't in any way offended. Right after my diagnosis I was kind of excited about the "opportunity" (?) to get new breasts at age 60!  Kind of warped, huh? I guess I was trying to make "lemonaid".  I was so devastated when I found out that wouldn't be an option.  It was like things just got worse and worse.  1 week after my BMX surgery I fell in the bathroom and had a deep laceration on my shoulder and an ER visit to get that sewed up. Then a week later I was in the ER again with a  small bowel obstruction. I have very bad veins and now with only one arm that can be used they had a difficult time getting a line in so that pain meds could be given.  That evening in the ER was like I was in a nightmare and I kept hoping I would out from the pain of the obstruction and torture of having an NG tube put down.  I was in the hospital for a week with an NG tube (the worst torture dreamed up by medicine as far as I'm concerned), IVs, and foley cath.  Breast surgery was a piece of cake compared to that. All that happened in a short period of time and I still am not feeling good.  I haven't been able to restart my multiple sclerosis meds yet and when I do I will have to have a port put in surgically so that the IV med can be givin.   Sometimes I feel like I'm having flashbacks to that time and I wonder about a little PTSD going on here.  It's definately not been a good 4 months.  I still don't want to have sex and when we do it makes me so sad.  I'm tearing up right now.
Posts.Title: I miss my breasts! topless karen1956

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2012 12:45PM topless wrote: Another nurse here!  I worked as an RN since 1973 but had to take early retirement because of worsening MS.  In 1974 I developed sudden onset fulmanating ulcerative colitis with toxic megacolon and had a panproctocolectomy and have lived with an ileostomy ever since.  I was diagnosed with MS in the early 80's and kept working until 2001.  Last August I underwent BMX for invasive mucinous breast cancer.  So I like to think I cured my ulcerative colitis and breast cancer but can't get rid of this pesky MS.  Sigh.
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2011 05:21PM topless wrote: Missing my breasts has very little to do with how I look - it's when  we get to that certain time during lovemaking when my husband usually plays with my breasts and his hands find - nothing. I feel embarrased and sad and angry.  And I no longer get any good feelings from my breasts so I feel cheated.  I'm not a candidate for reconstruction because of all the auto-immune diseases that I have and I'm O.K. with going flat.  That hasn't bothered me much.
